data.title: AHC: Alternate husband for Elizabeth II
data.meta_description: Whom else could she marry other than Prince Philip?
data.text:
Philip is alive but fine, she never falls in love with him

Philip remains in the Royal Navy, becomes First Sea Lord, and is the hero of the Falklands. He enters politics and replaces Thatcher as Prime Minister in 1990. He wins the 1992 election, but as expected retires in 1995, being replaced by Michael Heseltine, who is steamrolled by Gordon Brown n the 1997 General Election. Philip retires to the Lords with the hereditary title of Earl of Merioneth. He becomes a respected elder statesman in retirement and with his wife, the Countess of Merioneth, founds the Earl and Countess of Merioneth Foundations dedicated to the conservation of wildlife and in 2010, they earn the Noble Prize for peace.

He passed away in 2021.

Elizabeth marries some suitably titled German/Greek/Spanish minor royal in the early 1950's. She pops out a couple of children, but by the late 1960's is trapped in a near abusive marriage with a philandering husband. She turns to drink and drugs and the Royal Family falls in the public estimation., as the Sovereign is involved in an acrimonious divorce from the Prince Consort. Fortunately for her, she has begun a friendship with her distant cousin, Admiral of the Fleet Philip Mountbatten and his wife, which helps to keep of from falling off a cliff and regain sobriety and eventual public trust. Admiral Mountbatten's eventual Premiership furthers this.

When she dies suddenly in 1995, the Tory party leadership elections are delayed and the outgoing Prime Minister, Earl Merioneth presides over the mourning.

On the 25th anniversary of her death, a new book is published which claims that the Mountbatten/ Merioneths had arranged for the erstwhile Prince Consort to accept the divorce settlement.

Philip remains in the Royal Navy, becomes First Sea Lord, and is the hero of the Falklands. He enters politics and replaces Thatcher as Prime Minister in 1990. He wins the 1992 election, but as expected retires in 1995, being replaced by Michael Heseltine, who is steamrolled by Gordon Brown n the 1997 General Election. Philip retires to the Lords with the hereditary title of Earl of Merioneth. He becomes a respected elder statesman in retirement and with his wife, the Countess of Merioneth, founds the Earl and Countess of Merioneth Foundations dedicated to the conservation of wildlife and in 2010, they earn the Noble Prize for peace.

He passed away in 2021.

She pops out a couple of children, but by the late 1960's is trapped in a near abusive marriage with a philandering husband. She turns to drink and drugs and the Royal Family falls in the public estimation., as the Sovereign is involved in an acrimonious divorce from the Prince Consort. Admiral Mountbatten's eventual Premiership furthers this.

On the 25th anniversary of her death, a new book is published which claims that the Mountbatten/ Merioneths had arranged for the erstwhile Prince Consort to accept the divorce settlement.

I find it far more likely that she marries a domestic noble.German royalty is completely out of fashion at this point in time because of the two world wars.She couldn’t marry a Spanish royal because they are Catholics and are exiles.As for the Greeks, they aren’t important enough, and probably wouldn’t be chosen if she did not fall for Phillip.They whole concept of royalty marrying royalty was really coming to an end.Her own father didn’t marry any foreign royalty for example.

I find it far more likely that she marries a domestic noble.German royalty is completely out of fashion at this point in time because of the two world wars.She couldn’t marry a Spanish royal because they are Catholics and are exiles.As for the Greeks, they aren’t important enough, and probably wouldn’t be chosen if she did not fall for Phillip.They whole concept of royalty marrying royalty was really coming to an end.Her own father didn’t marry any foreign royalty for example.

Since he was not expected to become King. And strictly speaking, Elizabeth married a Greek Prince in OTL. Who converted.

While by that time lesser royals could and did marry nonroyalty (her parents for instance), it was still considered de riguer for the monarch and the heir to marry only royalty. One of the reasons why Philip was seen as suitable, its often forgotten but he was pretty high up in the Greek line of succession, no 2 at one point.

So I don't see a problem with her marrying into any family, conversions are easy and even German, with impeccable anti-Nazi credentials (like lots of ex-royals)

He wins the 1992 election, but as expected retires in 1995, being replaced by Michael Heseltine, who is steamrolled by Gordon Brown n the 1997 General Election. He becomes a respected elder statesman in retirement and with his wife, the Countess of Merioneth, founds the Earl and Countess of Merioneth Foundations dedicated to the conservation of wildlife and in 2010, they earn the Noble Prize for peace.

He passed away in 2021.

Admiral Mountbatten's eventual Premiership furthers this.

You miss a great opportunity with this story line. Instead of a divorce the prince consort dies in a polo match or boating accident. Phillip loses his wife (cancer, illnes, accident) . Lord Mountbatten helps Elizabeth after her husbands 'tragic' accident (There will be a LOT of stories about how the accident was planned) and she meets the widowed Phillip. The Press and public get entranced with this late romance and they are constantly seen together. They marry to public approval and live happily ever after.

Movie and TV rights are currently available
